questions.text: Match the correct antidote with the given drug toxicity: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzodiazepine: Flumazenil

 

Explanation: 


Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Mechanism - it acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. By competitively blocking these receptors, it can rapidly reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Atropine: L-carnitine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for atropine poisoning as it can reverse both peripheral and central anticholinergic effects. L-carnitine is used specifically for valproate-induced hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Barbiturate: Fomepizole: Incorrect. Barbiturates do not have a specific antidote - management involves alkalinization of urine to enhance excretion. Fomepizole is the antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Desferrioxamine: Incorrect. British Anti-Lewisite (BAL/Dimercaprol) is the antidote for arsenic poisoning. Desferrioxamine is specifically used for iron poisoning (both acute poisoning and chronic overload).

 

Educational Objective: 


Antidotes

questions.text: Which of the following statements about thyroxine is NOT true? (NEET PG  2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Decrease rate of respiration

 

Explanation:


Thyroxine (T4) is a major thyroid hormone that increases the metabolic rate of tissues. T4 has a calorigenic effect that increases heat production, oxygen consumption, and basal metabolic rate (BMR). With increased metabolism and oxygen demand, the respiratory rate would naturally increase rather than decrease to supply the additional oxygen needed, making option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increase BMR - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones have a calorigenic effect that increases heat production and basal metabolic rate. This is one of the primary physiological effects of thyroid hormones.
  • Option b. Increase oxygen consumption - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones directly increase oxygen consumption in most tissues of the body. This increased oxygen utilization supports the elevated metabolic processes.
  • Option d. Causes lipolysis - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones promote lipolysis, leading to decreased fat stores and increased utilization of cholesterol and triglycerides. This fat mobilization provides energy substrates for the increased metabolic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are catabolic hormones that increase metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, and energy utilization throughout the body, leading to increased (not decreased) respiratory rate to meet elevated oxygen demands.

questions.text: What is the source of the kidney parenchyma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c. Metanephros

 

Explanation:

 

The kidney parenchyma develops from the metanephros, which is the third and final set of kidneys to develop in the embryo. The metanephros gives rise to the definitive kidneys. The metanephric blastema (metanephric mesoderm), a specialized portion of the intermediate mesoderm, differentiates into the functional units of the kidney - the nephrons, including the glomeruli, proximal and distal convoluted tubules, and loops of Henle. These structures constitute the parenchyma of the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ureteric bud - This is incorrect because the ureteric bud, which is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct, forms the collecting system of the kidney - including the collecting tubules, calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter. It does not form the parenchyma (functional tissue) of the kidney.

 

Option B. Mesonephros - This is incorrect because the mesonephros is the second set of embryonic kidneys that degenerates in both males and females. In males, some of its ducts persist to form the efferent ductules, epididymis, and vas deferens. It does not contribute to the permanent kidney parenchyma.

 

Option D. Paramesonephros - This is incorrect because the paramesonephric ducts (Müllerian ducts) develop adjacent to the mesonephric ducts and give rise to female reproductive structures (fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper portion of the vagina). They are not involved in kidney development at all.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The metanephros is the permanent kidney that develops from intermediate mesoderm. It has two components: the metanephric blastema which forms the functional kidney parenchyma, and the ureteric bud which forms the collecting system.

questions.text: In which lobe of the brain is the supramarginal gyrus located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Parietal lobe

 

 

Explanation:

 

The supramarginal gyrus is located in the parietal lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. Specifically, it is a part of the inferior parietal lobule. The supramarginal gyrus is situated around the posterior end of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) and forms the anterior part of the inferior parietal lobule. It plays an important role in language function, particularly in the dominant hemisphere, and is involved in the processing of tactile and visual information to guide actions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b. Frontal lobe - The frontal lobe contains structures like the precentral gyrus (motor area), premotor area, and prefrontal cortex. It does not contain the supramarginal gyrus.

 

Option c. Temporal lobe - The temporal lobe contains structures such as the superior, middle, and inferior temporal gyri, as well as areas related to auditory processing and memory. The supramarginal gyrus is not part of this lobe.

 

Option d. Occipital lobe - The occipital lobe is primarily concerned with visual processing and contains the visual cortex. The supramarginal gyrus is not located in this lobe.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The supramarginal gyrus is a key component of the inferior parietal lobule in the parietal lobe and plays important roles in language processing, fine finger movements, and tongue movements, with integrated visual, auditory, and proprioceptive functions.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation, there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb, and the anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

The Rule of Nines, also known as Wallace's rule, is used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This method divides the body into sections, each accounting for approximately 9% (or multiples thereof) of the TBSA.

 

  • Left upper limb: Each upper limb is considered to account for 9% of the TBSA.
  • Right upper limb: Similarly, the right upper limb accounts for another 9%.
  • Anterior aspect of chest and abdomen: The anterior trunk, which includes the chest and abdomen, is considered to be 18% of the TBSA.

 

To calculate the total percentage of burns:

 

  • Left upper limb: 9%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Anterior chest and abdomen: 18%

 

Adding these together: 9%+9%+18%=36%

 

Thus, the patient has burns covering 36% of their body surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: Otosclerosis most commonly begins at which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fissula Ante-fenestram

 

Explanation:

 

Otosclerosis most commonly begins at the fissula ante fenestram. This is a small depression located in front of the oval window in the otic capsule. This is the initial site where the abnormal bone remodeling process begins, which eventually extends to involve the stapes footplate causing its fixation and conductive hearing loss. The fissula ante fenestrum is considered the classic starting point for otosclerotic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram: While otosclerotic foci can develop in various locations within the otic capsule, the fossula post-fenestram (behind the oval window) is not the most common initial site. Otosclerosis predominantly begins at the area anterior to the oval window (fissula ante fenestram).

 

Option C. Footplate of Stapes: Although the stapes footplate is eventually involved in otosclerosis, leading to the characteristic stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss, it is not typically the primary site where the disease process begins. The disease usually starts in the fissula ante fenestram and then extends to involve the footplate.

 

Option D. Oval Window: The oval window itself is not the initial site of otosclerotic change. The oval window is the opening between the middle and inner ear into which the stapes footplate fits. Otosclerosis begins in the bone adjacent to this structure (in the fissula ante fenestram) and then extends to involve the stapes footplate and oval window area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otosclerosis characteristically begins in the fissula ante fenestram (anterior to the oval window) before extending to involve the stapes footplate, causing the fixation that leads to conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is a significant rise in progesterone levels, which is crucial for the transformation of the endometrium into a secretory phase. This phase is essential for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation of an embryo.

 

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:

 

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days):
    • The shedding of the endometrial lining occurs if there is no pregnancy.
  2. Follicular Phase (10 - 14 days):
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
    • Estrogen levels rise, leading to the proliferation of the endometrium.
  3. Ovulation (14th day):
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH) surge leads to the release of an ovum from the dominant follicle.
  4. Luteal Phase (14 - 28 days):
    • The corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone.
    • Progesterone causes the endometrium to develop secretory glands and prepare for implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone: LH is primarily involved in triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum.

 

Option B. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone: FSH is crucial for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Estrogen is significant during the follicular phase for the proliferation of the endometrium but is not the main hormone acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the hormone responsible for preparing the endometrium for implantation during the post-ovulatory phase.

 

Ref: Page no 94, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

 

Explanation

 

  • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterovirus 70:

 

  • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.

 

Option D. VZV:

 

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: A patient with a mood disorder has been on medication and presents with new-onset liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valproate

 

Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing drug used to treat seizures, bipolar disorder, and to prevent migraine headaches. However, it is known to potentially cause hepatotoxicity (liver dysfunction) and hyperammonemia, especially when used in combination with other anticonvulsants or in patients with preexisting liver disease. Hepatotoxicity may be dose-dependent or idiosyncratic, and its risk is increased in the first six months of treatment, with higher doses, and with multiple antiepileptic drug regimens. Hyperammonemia occurs due to valproate’s interference with the urea cycle in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamotrigine: While lamotrigine can have side effects, it is more commonly associated with skin rashes and is not known to cause liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia as a typical adverse effect.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine can cause liver dysfunction but is less likely to cause hyperammonemia. It is more commonly associated with blood dyscrasias such as agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia.

 

Option D. Topiramate: This medication is not commonly associated with liver dysfunction or hyperammonemia. It has other side effects, such as weight loss, paresthesias, and cognitive slowing, but liver issues are not typically seen.

Therefore, in the context of a patient with mood disorder presenting with liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia, valproate is the most likely cause among the options provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate can cause hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia, making it the most likely culprit in patients presenting with these conditions while on medication for mood disorders.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient, who has been on anti-diabetic therapy for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of vaginal Candida infection in the past two months. Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin belongs to the class of drugs called SGLT2 inhibitors. These drugs work by increasing glucose excretion in the urine. While this helps lower blood sugar levels, it also creates an environment in the urogenital tract that is favorable for the growth of yeast like Candida, leading to increased risk of vaginal yeast infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin:  Metformin is a biguanide that works by decreasing glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity. It does not increase the risk of yeast infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates the pancreas to release more insulin. It does not have a direct impact on the urogenital tract or increase the risk of yeast infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It does not affect glucose levels in the urine and is not associated with an increased risk of yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors (drugs ending in "-gliflozin" - Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin) can increase the risk of urogenital infections, including vaginal candidiasis, due to increased glucose excretion in the urine. They should be used with caution or avoided in patients prone to such infections.

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids followed by FESS

 

Steroids followed by FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): This option is incorrect because steroids and FESS are primarily used for treating chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis. FESS is not an initial management option for CSF rhinorrhea; it is not related to repairing the skull base defect causing the CSF leak.

 

CSF rhinorrhea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose, often due to a defect in the skull base. Initial management focuses on conservative measures to allow spontaneous healing and to prevent complications such as meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bed rest: Advising the patient to take bed rest and avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure is a standard initial approach. This helps reduce the flow of CSF and may allow the defect to heal on its own.

 

Option C. HRCT (High-Resolution CT): HRCT is useful for diagnosing the exact site and cause of the CSF leak. It helps in planning further treatment if conservative measures fail.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and Acetazolamide: Antibiotics are given to prevent infections such as meningitis. Acetazolamide, a diuretic, reduces CSF production and intracranial pressure, which can help reduce the leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second pregnancy is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 30 weeks gestation. What is the drug of choice for her treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is the preferred treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during pregnancy due to its safety profile and ease of monitoring. LMWH does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus compared to other anticoagulants. Additionally, LMWH requires less frequent monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin, making it more convenient for both patients and healthcare providers during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can lead to fetal complications, including congenital malformations and bleeding. Warfarin is generally reserved for patients with specific conditions such as mechanical heart valves who were already on the drug before pregnancy, under careful supervision.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: While Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant, it is not the first-line choice for DVT in pregnancy. It is generally considered when LMWH is contraindicated, such as in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Apixaban: Apixaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), is not recommended in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. DOACs are generally avoided during pregnancy because they can cross the placenta and pose risks to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, the drug of choice for treating DVT is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) due to its safety and ease of monitoring compared to other anticoagulants

questions.text: Which condition is typically characterized by lesions described as "dew drop on rose petal"? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chicken Pox

 

Chicken Pox (Varicella) is classically characterized by lesions with a "dew drop on rose petal" appearance.

 

 

  • This distinctive description refers to clear, superficial vesicles (the "dew drops") that sit on an erythematous base (the "rose petal"). 
  • The vesicles of chicken pox are thin-walled and superficial, making them look like drops of water sitting on, rather than in, the skin. 
  • The irregular perivesicular erythema gives the lesions this characteristic appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum Contagiosum - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Molluscum contagiosum presents as pearly white, dome-shaped umbilicated papules. 

 

 

 

  • They do not have the "dew drop on rose petal" appearance but rather are characterized by a central umbilication from which cheesy material can be expressed.

 

Option C. Measles - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Measles presents with maculopapular confluent rash that is deep red to brown in color. 
  • The rash evolves in a cranio-caudal fashion and fades with scaling. 
  • It does not have vesicular lesions with the "dew drop on rose petal" appearance.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rosea - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a single "herald patch"

 

 

 

 

  • Followed by smaller oval lesions arranged in a "Christmas tree" pattern along the lines of Langer. 

 

 

 

 

  • The lesions are scaly with a collarette of scale, not vesicular with a "dew drop on rose petal" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "dew drop on rose petal" appearance is pathognomonic for chicken pox (varicella), describing its characteristic thin-walled, clear vesicles sitting on an erythematous base, appearing like water droplets on a rose petal.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options is not recommended for use during pregnancy? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Varicella

 

The Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women because it is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus, which can potentially cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to congenital infection or other complications. The primary concern is that the live virus, although weakened, may still pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy to minimize any potential risks to the fetus. Pregnant women are advised to receive inactivated vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens and are considered safer for both the mother and the unborn child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A:  The Hepatitis A vaccine is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. It is generally considered safe during pregnancy and can be administered if the benefits outweigh the risks, especially if the woman is at high risk for Hepatitis A infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B:  The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, which does not contain live virus. It is safe to use during pregnancy and is recommended for pregnant women who are at risk of Hepatitis B infection.

 

Option C. Rabies:  The Rabies vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. It is considered safe during pregnancy and should be administered if there is a risk of rabies exposure, as the disease itself is fatal if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The development of cataracts in patients with Diabetes Mellitus is primarily due to the accumulation of which of the following substances in the lens? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sorbitol

 

In diabetes mellitus, high blood glucose leads to increased glucose entry into the sorbitol pathway. Glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase using NADPH as a cofactor. 

 

Normally, sorbitol is further converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase. 

 

However, in diabetes, excess glucose leads to accumulation of sorbitol in the lens. Being hygroscopic, sorbitol draws water into lens cells causing osmotic stress and swelling, ultimately leading to snowflake cataract formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dulcitol: This is actually the same as galactitol, which accumulates in galactosemia causing oil drop cataracts, not diabetic cataracts. Dulcitol accumulation happens due to conversion of excess galactose by aldose reductase in galactosemia.

 

Option C. Mannitol: This is a sugar alcohol used therapeutically to decrease intracranial tension. It does not accumulate in diabetic cataracts.

 

Option D. Galactitol: This accumulates in galactosemia causing oil drop cataracts, not diabetic cataracts. It is formed when excess galactose is converted by aldose reductase.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diabetic cataract (snowflake cataract) occurs due to sorbitol accumulation via the polyol pathway, whereas galactosemia leads to oil drop cataract due to galactitol/dulcitol accumulation.

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic artery

 

The image provided shows an intraoperative view during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, focusing on the Calot's triangle. This area is critical for identifying key anatomical structures to safely remove the gallbladder.

 

Calot's triangle is bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver. The "critical view of safety" is a surgical technique used to clearly identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct before clipping and cutting them.

 

In the image, the marked structure is the inner one, closer to the liver. This inner structure is the cystic artery. The outer structure, which is away from the liver and entering the gallbladder, is the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic duct: The cystic duct is the tube that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. In the image, it is the outer structure marked CD, which is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option C. Right hepatic artery: This artery supplies blood to the right lobe of the liver and is not typically involved in the structures identified within Calot's triangle during a cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is part of the biliary duct system, joining with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: NADPH is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fatty acid synthesis

 

NADPH is essential for fatty acid synthesis. During this process, NADPH provides reducing equivalents necessary for the conversion of acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. This reduction step is crucial for building the carbon chains that make up fatty acids, and NADPH acts as a reducing agent in this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketone Synthesis: NADPH is not directly involved in ketone synthesis. Ketones are typically synthesized from fatty acids during a state of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: NADPH plays a role in gluconeogenesis, which is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. NADPH is required for certain enzymatic reactions in this pathway, such as the reduction of oxaloacetate to malate.

 

Option D. Glycolysis: NADPH is not directly involved in glycolysis. Glycolysis primarily uses NAD+ (Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide) rather than NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH generating reactions

 

  1. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phospho-glucono lactone)
  2. 6-phospho gluconate dehydrogenase in the shunt pathway (6-phospho gluconate → 3-keto-6-phospho gluconate)
  3. Cytoplasmic isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Malic enzyme (malate to pyruvate).

 

NADPH utilizing reactions

 

  1. Ketoacyl-ACP dehydrogenase (Beta-ketoacyl-ACP → beta hydroxy acyl ACP) (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 4)
  2. Alpha, beta unsaturated acyl ACP → Acyl ACP (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 6)
  3. HMG CoA reductase (HMG CoA → mevalonate (Cholesterol synthesis)
  4. Met-hemoglobin → Hemoglobin
  5. Folate reductase (Folate → dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate)
  6. Phenyl alanine hydroxylase (Phenylalanine → tyrosine)

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

 

The symptoms of ptosis and diplopia that worsen with activity and improve with rest are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

The most sensitive investigation for myasthenia gravis is single fiber electromyography (SF-EMG), which detects abnormalities in the neuromuscular transmission by measuring the electrical activity of muscle fibers. Even if single fiber EMG is not specifically mentioned, standard EMG is still highly sensitive and appropriate for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. Another practical test used is repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS), which shows a decremental response in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT scan chest: This is usually performed in confirmed myasthenia gravis patients to rule out thymoma, but it is not the most sensitive test for diagnosing the condition itself.

 

Option C. Acetylcholinesterase test: Also known as the edrophonium test or Tensilon test, this can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle strength. However, it has variable sensitivity and specificity and is less sensitive than EMG.

 

Option D. Nerve conduction velocity: This test is more relevant in the diagnosis of neuropathies, particularly demyelinating neuropathies, where conduction velocities are decreased. It is not the most sensitive test for myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in glomerular basement membrane?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heparan Sulfate

 

Heparan sulfate is a major component of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It plays a crucial role in the molecular organization and function of the GBM. Heparan sulfate proteoglycans help maintain the integrity and selective permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier in the kidney, preventing the passage of large molecules like proteins into the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is not typically found in the glomerular basement membrane. It is a component of other connective tissues and structures in the body.

 

Option C. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) but is not a proteoglycan. It is found in various tissues and synovial fluid in joints but is not a major component of the glomerular basement membrane.

 

Option D. Dermatan sulfate: Dermatan sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan (GAG) but is not a proteoglycan commonly associated with the glomerular basement membrane. It is found in various connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GAGs (Location and Function)

 

 

 Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 602

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and is diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia without atypia based on an endometrial biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)

 

Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is a premalignant condition caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, leading to excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands. 

 

The primary concern with endometrial hyperplasia is its potential progression to endometrial carcinoma, though the risk is much lower in cases without atypia (approximately 1%).

 

LNG-IUS (Mirena) -progesterone is the mainstay treatment because it induces endometrial atrophy and prevents further proliferation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. COCPs (Incorrect): Although Combined contraceptive pills are protective for endometrial cancer, they are not a treatment option for endometrial hyperplasia due to the estrogen component. 

 

Option C. Danazol (Incorrect): Danazol is an antigonadotropin with significant androgenic side effects. While it was historically used for endometriosis, it is not used for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Mifepristone (Incorrect): Mifepristone is primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy and occasionally for emergency contraception or fibroid treatment. It is not indicated for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that LNG-IUS is the preferred treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia due to its local progesterone delivery, which causes endometrial atrophy. This condition has a lower risk of malignancy (~1%) compared to hyperplasia with atypia, which requires hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) is the main factor controlling the closure of the ductus arteriosus postnatally. Oxygen acts as a potent smooth muscle constrictor. When a newborn begins to breathe and cries, oxygen enters the lungs during inspiration, leading to an increase in paO2. This increased oxygen tension causes the smooth muscle in the ductus arteriosus to constrict, leading to its closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance: While systemic vascular resistance does increase after birth due to the cessation of placental circulation, it is not the primary factor responsible for ductal closure.

 

Option C. Increase in circulating prostaglandin levels: Prostaglandins, particularly PGE2, help keep the ductus arteriosus open. After birth, the levels of circulating prostaglandins decrease, contributing to ductal closure, but an increase in prostaglandins would not cause closure.

 

Option D. Decrease in pulmonary venous resistance: Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth as the lungs expand and fill with air, allowing blood to flow more easily through the pulmonary circulation. However, this is not the direct cause of ductal closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) postnatally is the most important factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least conduction velocity? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Postganglionic sympathetic fibers

 

Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, also known as type C fibers, are known for their small diameter and lack of myelin sheath, characteristics that contribute to their slow conduction velocity compared to other nerve fiber types. These fibers are involved in the sympathetic nervous system, carrying impulses from the autonomic ganglia to the target organs. The absence of myelin significantly reduces their conduction speed because myelin acts as an insulator that enhances the speed of nerve impulse conduction through saltatory conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic motor fibers: These fibers, typically myelinated and larger in diameter, conduct impulses much faster. They are involved in controlling voluntary muscle movements.

 

Option C. Pre-ganglionic autonomic fibers: Generally myelinated though smaller than somatic motor fibers, pre-ganglionic fibers also conduct impulses faster than postganglionic sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Touch and pressure fibers: These sensory fibers are usually myelinated and conduct impulses at high speeds, facilitating rapid response to sensory stimuli.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Conduction Velocity Factors: The speed at which a nerve fiber conducts an electrical impulse is influenced by its diameter and whether or not it is myelinated. Larger diameter and myelination both contribute to faster conduction velocities.
  • Type C Fibers: These are the smallest and slowest conducting fibers due to their lack of myelination. They typically transmit nociceptive (pain) and sympathetic autonomic signals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options given, postganglionic sympathetic fibers (Type C fibers) have the least conduction velocity due to their small diameter and lack of myelin, which make them slower in transmitting nerve impulses compared to myelinated fibers.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the following image. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

  • The Salter-Harris classification system is used to describe fractures involving the growth plate (physis) in children. 
  • The types range from I to V, with increasing severity:
    • Type I: Slip or separation of the growth plate.
    • Type II: Fracture that involves a part of the metaphysis and the growth plate. This is the most common type and is also known as the Thurston-Holland sign.
    • Type III: Fracture through the growth plate and epiphysis, involving the joint surface, causing epiphyseal split.
    • Type IV: Fracture through the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.
    • Type V: Compression/crush injury to the growth plate with initially normal x-ray.

 

 

  • In the provided image, the fracture depicted involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis, which classifies it as a Type II injury.
  • Remember: 
    • MC type is Type II.
    • Location of Epiphyseal Injuries: When it comes to epiphyseal injuries, particularly in pediatric cases, these injuries typically occur through the zone of hypertrophy of the growth plate. This zone is one of the layers of the growth plate where chondrocytes mature and enlarge before the end of the bone lengthens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Type I: Involves only the growth plate without extending into the metaphysis or epiphysis.

 

Option Type III: Involves the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

 

Option Type IV: Involves the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children.
  • A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.

questions.text: A patient with a bleeding disorder is suspected of having von Willebrand disease. What does vWF primarily bind to in the process of platelet adhesion? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gp Ib/IX

 

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is a large multimeric glycoprotein that plays an important role in primary hemostasis. In the process of platelet adhesion, vWF primarily binds to glycoprotein Ib/IX complex (GpIb/IX) on the platelet surface. This interaction is essential for platelet adhesion to damaged endothelium, particularly under high shear stress conditions like those found in small arteries and arterioles. VWF is produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes and is stored in Weibel-Palade bodies within endothelial cells. When vessel injury occurs, vWF functions as a bridge between exposed subendothelial collagen and platelets through the GpIb/IX receptor complex, initiating the hemostatic process.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gp IIb: Glycoprotein IIb (GpIIb) is part of the GpIIb/IIIa complex on platelets, which binds fibrinogen during platelet aggregation, not platelet adhesion. GpIIb/IIIa is involved in platelet-platelet interaction (aggregation), whereas vWF-GpIb/IX interaction is critical for platelet-endothelium interaction (adhesion). Defects in GpIIb/IIIa result in Glanzmann thrombasthenia, not von Willebrand disease.

 

Option B. Prothrombin: Prothrombin (Factor II) is a coagulation factor that is converted to thrombin during the coagulation cascade. While thrombin is a potent activator of platelets, it doesn't interact directly with vWF during the initial adhesion process.

 

Option D. ADP: Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) is a platelet agonist released from platelet dense granules upon activation. It binds to platelet ADP receptors (P2Y1 and P2Y12) and promotes platelet aggregation. While important in platelet function, ADP is not a binding partner for vWF in the adhesion process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to glycoprotein Ib/IX (GpIb/IX) on platelets during the initial adhesion process, which is essential for normal hemostasis. Deficiency or dysfunction of VWF results in von Willebrand disease, characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding due to impaired platelet adhesion.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanism doesn’t require ATP: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The image shows four different transport mechanisms across cell membranes:

 

1. Simple diffusion through membrane: This shows direct diffusion of molecules through the lipid bilayer from high concentration to low concentration. This is also passive transport that doesn't require ATP.

 

2. Simple diffusion through channels: This shows molecules moving through a protein channel from high concentration to low concentration. This is passive transport that follows the concentration gradient without requiring ATP. Channels have gates that simply open or close without configurational changes, allowing molecules to pass according to their concentration gradient.

 

3. Paracellular transport: This shows molecules moving between cells through the spaces between adjacent cells, not through the cells themselves. This is passive movement along the concentration gradient and doesn't require ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Active transport: This shows fewer molecules on one side and more on the other side, indicating movement against the concentration gradient (from low to high concentration). This requires energy in the form of ATP to power the transport proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple diffusion through membrane, Simple diffusion through channels, Paracellular transport do not require ATP as they represent forms of passive transport, while Active transport requiring ATP

choices.text: Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception.
Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills.
Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination.
Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

 

Explanation:


Cochlear implants do not increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation. In fact, the opposite is true - cochlear implants often help reduce tinnitus in most patients who experience it prior to implantation. The electrical stimulation provided by the implant can mask or suppress the tinnitus sensation. Studies show that cochlear implantation can reduce or even eliminate pre-existing tinnitus in approximately 70-80% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception: This statement is true. Cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing for improved detection and discrimination of sounds. This leads to enhanced speech perception and better understanding of environmental sounds.

 

Option B. Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills: This statement is true, especially for children who receive implants early. Early implantation (before 6 years of age in pre-lingual deaf children) allows for better development of auditory pathways and improved chances of developing age-appropriate speech and language skills.

 

Option C. Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination: This statement is true. Cochlear implants help improve sound discrimination abilities, allowing recipients to better distinguish between different sounds. Bilateral implantation particularly improves sound localization abilities by providing binaural cues necessary for spatial hearing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Contrary to increasing tinnitus, cochlear implants typically reduce or suppress pre-existing tinnitus in most patients due to the masking effect of electrical stimulation and reorganization of central auditory pathways following implantation.

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter of the skull is smallest in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Brachycephaly

 

Explanation:

 

Brachycephaly (short-headed) is characterized by a skull that has a short anteroposterior diameter compared to its width. This is reflected in the cephalic index formula:

Cephalic Index = (Maximum transverse breadth of skull / Maximum anteroposterior length of skull) × 100

 

Brachycephalic skulls have a cephalic index of 80-85 and are found in Mongoloids. This high index value indicates that the width is large relative to a shorter anteroposterior length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dolichocephaly (Incorrect) Dolichocephalic (long-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 70-75. This indicates a longer anteroposterior diameter relative to width, not shorter.

 

Option B. Mesocephaly (Incorrect) Mesaticephalic (medium-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 75-80. This represents an intermediate anteroposterior diameter.

 

Option D. Trigonocephaly (Incorrect) Trigonocephaly refers to a condition where the skull has a triangular appearance when viewed from above due to premature fusion of the metopic suture. It's not directly classified in the cephalic index system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic index measures the ratio between skull width and length - the higher the index (as in brachycephaly), the shorter the anteroposterior diameter relative to width.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to you with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal os

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of placenta previa which is caused due to placental implantation at the internal os.
  • Although the term placenta previa is diagnosed after 28 weeks, it can present with profuse bleeding at earlier gestational ages also.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: This will not present as profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks. This will present at a much earlier gestational age (6-8 weeks) and presents with abdominal pain (ruptured ectopic), vaginal bleeding (not profuse) and amenorrhoea (6-8 weeks)

 

Option C. Ovarian: Presents like an ectopic in the fallopian tube

 

Option D. Abdominal: This has varied presentations, but doesn’t present with profuse vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental implantation at the internal os, causing placenta previa, can lead to profuse vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 657, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the X-Ray image shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jejunal atresia

 

The X-ray image provided shows a characteristic feature known as the "triple bubble" appearance, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. In the context of pediatric radiology, this appearance is caused by the presence of three dilated gas-filled bowel loops proximal to the atretic segment of the jejunum. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an obstruction in the jejunum, leading to this distinctive radiological sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: This condition typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on an X-ray, not a triple bubble. The double bubble sign shows two dilated areas—one in the stomach and one in the duodenum—due to an obstruction in the duodenum.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. The X-ray sign is free air under the diaphragm, which is not seen in the given image.

 

Option D. Hirschsprung’s disease: This is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to obstruction. The radiographic features might include a distended colon with a transition zone, but it does not present with the triple bubble appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological findings:

 

  • Jejunal atresia or ileal atresia: Triple Bubble Appearance
  • Duodenal atresia: Double Bubble sign
  • Infantile pyloric stenosis: Single Bubble sign

questions.text: Testosterone is produced by which of the following cells? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Leydig cells

 

Explanation:


Testosterone is primarily produced by the Leydig cells located in the interstitial tissue of the testes. These cells synthesize testosterone in response to luteinizing hormone (LH) stimulation. Testosterone is classified as a sex steroid derived from cholesterol like other steroid hormones. The steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR) plays a crucial role in testosterone synthesis by facilitating cholesterol transport across mitochondrial membranes - the rate-limiting first step in steroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Sertoli cells - These cells are located within the seminiferous tubules and support spermatogenesis but do not produce testosterone. They respond to testosterone rather than producing it.
  • Option C. Germinal epithelium - This refers to the epithelial layer that lines the seminiferous tubules and contains developing sperm cells. It is not involved in testosterone production.
  • Option D. Seminiferous tubules - These are the sites of spermatogenesis within the testes. While they require testosterone for proper function, they do not produce it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone synthesis occurs in Leydig cells through the steroidogenic pathway that begins with cholesterol transport via StAR protein and involves subsequent enzymatic conversions to produce this essential male sex hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the most appropriate management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ART immediately and continue life long

 

Explanation:

 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) recommends that all pregnant women with HIV should start antiretroviral therapy (ART) immediately, regardless of the stage of their disease or their CD4 count. This approach is aimed at reducing the viral load as quickly as possible, thereby decreasing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. ART should be continued lifelong to ensure ongoing viral suppression and the health of the mother.

 

Management of HIV-positive pregnancy includes:

 

  1. Antenatal care:
    • Testing for other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), CMV, toxoplasmosis, tuberculosis, fungal, and other opportunistic infections.
    • Partner/husband should also be tested.
    • To prevent pneumocystis pneumonia, start co-trimoxazole if CD4 count is ≤ 250 cells/mm³ and continue through pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding (dose: double strength tablet, 1 tablet daily).
    • Assess immunization status and update as needed.
    • Counseling on the impact of HIV on pregnancy and factors influencing the progression of the disease and risk of perinatal transmission.
    • CD4 count testing in each trimester.
    • Monitor HIV RNA levels monthly after changing/initiating therapy.
    • CBC, LFT, and KFT in each trimester.
  2. Anti-retroviral therapy for all:
    • As per NACO: Start ART at diagnosis (regardless of CD4 count); continue lifelong.
    • Initiate lifelong ART in all pregnant women with confirmed HIV infection regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 cell count.
    • TDF + 3TC + EFV is recommended as first-line ART in pregnant and breastfeeding women (including pregnant women in the first trimester of pregnancy).
    • Pregnant women detected to be HIV-positive for the first time in labor should be initiated on ART (TDF + 3TC + EFV) immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Start ART immediately upon diagnosis of HIV in pregnancy and continue lifelong to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission and maintain the health of the mother.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with painful vesicular lesions on her lips. A Tzanck smear from the lesions shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

 

HSV is the causative agent in this case, as evidenced by the characteristic painful vesicular lesions on the lips and the presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear. HSV typically causes painful, fluid-filled vesicles that can occur on the lips (usually HSV-1) or genitals (usually HSV-2). The Tzanck smear finding of multinucleated giant cells is pathognomonic for herpes virus infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): Typically causes mononucleosis with systemic symptoms and doesn't cause vesicular lesions on the lips.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Usually causes systemic infection in immunocompromised patients and doesn't typically cause oral lesions.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus (HPV): Causes warts and papillomas, not vesicular lesions. It also doesn't show multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV infection is characterized by painful vesicular lesions and the presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear, which is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman has presented with symptoms of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation, bad breath, and cough. He also exhibits bilateral lung crepitations upon examination. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects patients over 60 years of age, matching our elderly patient's demographic. The classic symptoms include dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food (especially at night when recumbent), halitosis (bad breath), and cough with aspiration pneumonia (explaining the bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Visual Support

 

Zenker's diverticulum occurs when herniation of pouch starts in the midline. It is at first behind the esophagus and then comes to lie on its left. The mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of esophagus, so food preferentially enters the sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a narrow ring of tissue at the lower end of the esophagus and would not cause regurgitation of undigested food or aspiration pneumonia. It typically presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids only, not the constellation of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This is a motility disorder (diffuse esophageal spasm) characterized by non-peristaltic contractions. While it can cause dysphagia, it does not lead to regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This condition is characterized by hypochromic microcytic anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal webs. It typically affects women in their 40s and 50s, not elderly men. It is not associated with regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration, as the pouch traps food that can later be regurgitated and aspirated.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Assertion is false, reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria.


Reason: It is due to bacteremia.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, reason is false

 

Explanation:

 

The assertion that myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria is correct. Myocarditis is a well-known and serious complication of diphtheria, often leading to significant morbidity and mortality.

 

The reason provided, that myocarditis is due to bacteremia, is incorrect. The complications of diphtheria, including myocarditis, are primarily due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not bacteremia. The toxin affects various organs, including the heart, leading to myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a complication of diphtheria caused by the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not by bacteremia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not cause conductive hearing loss? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endolymphatic Hydrops

 

Explanation:


Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathological condition underlying Ménière's disease. It involves an excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear's membranous labyrinth, particularly affecting the cochlea. This condition causes sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) because it affects the sensory hair cells in the cochlea. The hearing loss in Ménière's disease is typically fluctuating and predominantly affects the lower frequencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerosis: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to its fixation in the oval window. This prevents normal transmission of sound vibrations from the middle ear to the inner ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss of up to 60 dB.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Also known as otitis media with effusion, it involves accumulation of non-purulent fluid in the middle ear space. This fluid impedes the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, resulting in conductive hearing loss typically ranging from 20-40 dB.

 

Option D. Suppurative otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Acute or chronic suppurative otitis media involves infection of the middle ear with purulent discharge. The presence of pus in the middle ear and/or perforation of the tympanic membrane interferes with sound transmission, resulting in conductive hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière's disease) is an inner ear disorder causing sensorineural hearing loss, while conditions affecting the external or middle ear (otosclerosis, otitis media) cause conductive hearing loss by interfering with the mechanical transmission of sound to the inner ear.

questions.text: The four-layer suture repair of an inguinal hernia with double breasting of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Shouldice operation

 

Explanation:

 

The Shouldice operation is specifically characterized as a four-layer herniorrhaphy technique that involves double breasting of the conjoint tendon, inguinal ligament, and the two halves of the fascia transversalis to create a reinforced posterior wall repair. This multi-layered approach creates a strong repair using local tissues without mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Lichtenstein operation: This is a tension-free hernioplasty that uses a polypropylene mesh placed on top of the posterior wall (onlay repair). It does not involve double breasting of local tissues or a four-layer repair.
  • Option C. Stoppa operation: This is a preperitoneal mesh repair technique primarily used for complex or recurrent hernias. It involves placing a large mesh in the preperitoneal space, not a four-layer tissue repair.
  • Option D. Bassini repair: While this is also a herniorrhaphy technique, it involves suturing the conjoint tendon to the inguinal ligament using interrupted sutures. It does not include the four-layer double breasting technique that defines the Shouldice repair.

 

Comparison of hernia repair techniques:

  • Herniorrhaphy: Strengthening of the posterior wall using locally available tissue 
    • Bassini: Simple suturing of conjoint tendon to inguinal ligament
    • Shouldice: Double-breasting with 4-layer posterior wall repair
    • Desarda: Uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis
  • Hernioplasty: Use of prosthetic material (mesh) 
    • Lichtenstein: Onlay mesh repair

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Shouldice repair is distinguished by its meticulous four-layer closure technique with double-breasting of the posterior wall tissues, creating a strong anatomical repair without the use of prosthetic material.

choices.text: Increased formation of Heinz body
Males and females can be affected
Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells' ability to handle oxidative stress.

 

This is incorrect. G6PD deficiency actually increases oxidative stress inside red blood cells because the reduced NADPH levels lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione. This makes the cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased formation of Heinz body: Correct because this is a hallmark of G6PD deficiency due to oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Males and females can be affected: Correct; while males are more commonly affected, females can also be affected due to the X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option C. Reduced NADPH: Correct because this is a direct consequence of G6PD deficiency as the enzyme is essential for NADPH production in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Halothane

 

The symptoms described in the scenario—tachycardia, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity—are classic signs of malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening condition that can be triggered by certain anesthetic agents, most notably volatile anesthetics like halothane and depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. Halothane is one of the most well-known triggers of malignant hyperthermia, especially in genetically susceptible individuals. The condition is due to an abnormal release of calcium in muscle cells, leading to intense muscle contractions, increased metabolism, and excessive heat production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol is a widely used intravenous anesthetic agent that does not trigger malignant hyperthermia. Instead, it is often used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia due to its favorable safety profile.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate is another intravenous anesthetic commonly used for induction, particularly in patients with cardiovascular instability. Like propofol, it does not trigger malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is a carrier gas that provides analgesia and sedation but is not associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia. It is often used in combination with other anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Halothane, a volatile anesthetic, is a known trigger for malignant hyperthermia, characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia, especially in genetically predisposed individuals.

choices.text: Do UPT and then give DMPA

questions.text: A female patient taking DMPA came 14 days late. What should be advised to her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give DMPA, no backup required

 

When a patient is up to 15 days late for a Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection, it is generally safe to administer the injection without additional contraceptive backup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do UPT and then give DMPA: Pregnancy testing is typically not required unless the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option B. DMPA + 7 days backup: Backup contraception is recommended if the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option C. DMPA from next cycle: There is no need to wait until the next cycle if the delay is within 15 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients receiving DMPA who are less than 15 days late for their injection, it can be administered without the need for additional contraceptive measures or delay.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anosmia

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the failure to start or fully complete puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from an isolated deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and consequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Anosmia is the hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome and helps differentiate it from other causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndactyly in males: This refers to the fusion of fingers or toes and is not characteristic of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Precocious puberty in females: This is an early onset of puberty, which is not associated with Kallmann syndrome, as this condition causes delayed or absent puberty.

 

Option D. White forelock: This is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, not Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
