Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a smoker patient who presented as shown in the given image and the next investigation required in the management of this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythroplakia and Biopsy

 

The image shows a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa of a smoker. This presentation is characteristic of erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is known to have a high risk of malignant transformation, making it a precancerous lesion. Given its potential for developing into oral cancer, the next step in management is to perform a biopsy. A biopsy will allow for histopathological examination to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma, which is critical for guiding further treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia and observation: Observation alone is not appropriate for erythroplakia due to its high risk of malignancy. A biopsy is necessary to assess the lesion.

 

Option C. Leukoplakia and Biopsy: Leukoplakia is characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes, which is not consistent with the red lesion shown in the image.

 

Option D. Leukoplakia and observation: Similar to option C, leukoplakia refers to white patches, and observation alone is not recommended for high-risk lesions without first performing a biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythroplakia presents as a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa and has a high risk of malignant transformation. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a biopsy to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Upper end of the tibia

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants is the upper end (proximal portion) of the tibia, specifically the anteromedial surface of the proximal tibial metaphysis, approximately 1-2 cm below the tibial tuberosity. This site is preferred in infants because:

  • It is easily accessible and has minimal overlying soft tissue
  • The cortex is relatively thin, making penetration easier
  • It is distant from vital structures like the heart and lungs
  • The proximal tibial growth plate does not close until later in childhood
  • It allows stable positioning of the infant during the procedure

 

In infants under 12-18 months of age, the tibial marrow cavity is still highly cellular and provides adequate samples for diagnostic purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternum - Incorrect. The sternum is not recommended as a site for bone marrow aspiration in infants due to the risk of serious complications, particularly cardiac or great vessel puncture. The sternum is too thin in infants and the proximity to vital structures makes this site dangerous.

 

Option B. Spinous process of lumbar vertebra - Incorrect. The spinous processes of vertebrae are not used for bone marrow aspiration at any age. This site would be both technically difficult and dangerous due to proximity to the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Lower end of femur - Incorrect. While the distal femur can be used as an alternative site for bone marrow aspiration in infants, it is not the preferred first-line site. The proximal tibia offers better access and is generally easier to perform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper end of the tibia is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants under 12-18 months of age due to its accessibility, thinner cortex, distance from vital structures, and adequate cellularity.

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.
